descript.abstract:
The Soil Name Table (SNT) describes the general physical and chemical characteristics for all of the soils identified in a geographic region. Soil Order, Great Group and Subgroup are listed, along with attributes such as mode of deposition, and drainage class.
The latest version is available here.
descript.purpose: The Alberta Soil Name Table (SNT) forms part of the Soil Information Database for the province of Alberta (ABSID)
descript.supplinf: Additional information can be found on the Canadian Soil Information System (CanSIS) website at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/dss/v3/index.html

citeinfo.origin: Government of Canada / Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada (AAFC)
citeinfo.title: Alberta Soil Layer Table (SLT)

crossref.assndesc: The Soil Layer Table (SLT) describes the chemical and physical properties for each layer (horizon) associated with each soil listed in the SNT. The SNT is connected to the SLT through the common SOIL_ID field via a one-to-many (1:N) relationship.

citeinfo.origin: Government of Canada / Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada (AAFC)
citeinfo.title: Alberta Component Table (CMP)

pubinfo.publish: Government of Canada / Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada (AAFC)

crossref.assndesc: The Component File (CMP) contains the soil and landscape elements required to characterize a soil polygon, for one or more distinct soil components. The SNT is connected to the CMP through the common SOIL_ID field via a one-to-many (1:N) relationship.

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata

cntorgp.cntorg: Government of Canada/Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada (AAFC)

attr.attrdef: Soil Name Identifier: This field is normally used to join the Soil Names Table (SNT) to other tables such as the Component Table (CMP). There is only one record in the SNT for any given SOIL_ID. This field is a concatenation of the PROVINCE + SOIL_CODE + MODIFIER + PROFILE fields.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/soil_id.html

attr.attrdef: Province Code: A two-character province code used as part of a link to the CanSIS NAMES and LAYERS tables.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/province.html

edom.edomvd: Alberta:
British Columbia:
Prince Edward Island:
New Brunswick:
Ontario:
Manitoba:
Nova Scotia:
Newfoundland and Labrador:
Saskatchewan:
Quebec:
Yukon:
Northwest Territories:
Nunavut:

attr.attrdef: Soil Code: Soil code used as part of the link to a representative soil in the CanSIS NAMES and LAYERs tables. The "#" symbol is used to denote non-applicable for areas where no soil name is established.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/soil_code.html

attr.attrdef: Soil Code Modifier: The modifier code is used to indicate a particular assemblage of characteristics related to a soil code. A soil modifier code is used as part of the link to a representative soil in the Soil Name and Soil Layer tables. The soil_code + modifier are unique within each Province or Territory for all soils (mineral or organic), nonsoils, and unclassified areas.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/modifier.html

attr.attrdef: Type of soil profile: Indicates the type of soil profile (agricultural or native). Used as part of the linkage key to the NAMES (SNT) and LAYERS (SLT) tables. The linkage is made to an agricultural model of each soil profile, where it is available (PROFILE = A). This “agricultural bias” is useful for agricultural interpretive modeling. True land use information should be consulted to determine the current land use in a particular soil map polygon.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/profile.html

edom.edomvd: Native soil profile: The soil is in native condition (undisturbed by agriculture).
Agricultural soil profile: The soil has been disturbed by agriculture.

attr.attrdef: Soil Name: Complete soil name, without abbreviations. There may be multiple records in the SNT for any given SOILNAME.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/soilname.html

attr.attrdef: Kind of Surface Material: Identifies the kind of surface soil, rock outcrop or other material (feature). First used in SLC 3.0.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/kind.html

edom.edomvd: Mineral: The soil material is primarily composed of mineral particles.
Organic: The soil material is primarily composed of organic particles.
True Non-soil: This is a true non-soil (e.g. airport or lake).
Unclassified: This material was not classified due to an absence of information or an unusual situation, such as rockland or an extremely shallow soil.

attr.attrdef: Water Table Characteristics: Indicates the presence of a water table at a depth of 100cm, and identifies its temporal characteristics.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/watertbl.html

edom.edomvd: Always: The water table is always present in the soil.
Growing season: The water table is present in the soil during the growing season.
Non growing season: The water table is present in the soil during the non growing season.
Unspecified period: The water table is present in the soil during an unspecified period.
Never: The water table is not present in the soil at any time.
Not applicable: Not applicable.

attr.attrdef: Soil layer that restricts root growth: Indicates the soil layer that restricts root growth. "-" indicates "not applicable". Layers are numbered 0 if no restricting layer is present. Numbers 1-9 indicate that the layer is restrictive and this number can be linked to the LAYER_NO field in the SLT.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/rootrestri.html

edom.edomvd: First layer: The growth of plant roots is restricted by the first (uppermost) layer.
Not applicable: Non-applicable (e.g. rock, ice).
No root restricting layer: The growth of plant roots is not restricted by any soil layer.
Second layer: The growth of plant roots is restricted by the second layer.
Third layer: The growth of plant roots is restricted by the third layer.
Fourth layer: The growth of plant roots is restricted by the fourth layer.
Fifth layer: The growth of plant roots is restricted by the fifth layer.
Sixth layer: The growth of plant roots is restricted by the sixth layer.
Seventh layer: The growth of plant roots is restricted by the seventh layer.
Eighth layer: The growth of plant roots is restricted by the eighth layer.
Ninth layer: The growth of plant roots is restricted by the ninth layer.

attr.attrdef: Type of root restricting layer: Indicates the type of soil in the root restricting layer.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/restr_type.html

edom.edomvd: Undifferentiated: Undifferentiated
Solonetzic: Solonetzic B horizon
Salinity: Salinity (conductivity > 4 dS/m)
Compact Till: Compact (Basal) Till
Ortstein: Ortstein horizon
Fragipan: Fragipan
Lithic: Lithic (consolidated bedrock)
Cryic: Cryic (frozen) horizon
Duric: Duric horizon
Placic: Placic horizon
n/a: Not Applicable

attr.attrdef: Soil Drainage Class: Indicates the type of drainage found within a soil profile. First used in SLC 3.0. Identical classes to drainage in SLC 1.0, but codes differ.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/drainage.html

edom.edomvd: Very rapidly drained: Water is removed from the soil very rapidly in relation to supply. Excess water flows downward very rapidly if underlying material is pervious. There may be very rapid subsurface flow during heavy rainfall provided there is a steep gradient. Soils have very low available water storage capacity (usually less than 2.5 cm) within the control section and are usually coarse textured, or shallow, or both. Water source is precipitation.

Rapidly drained: Water is removed from the soil rapidly in relation to supply. Excess water flows downward if underlying material is pervious. Subsurface flow may occur on steep gradients during heavy rainfall. Soils have low available water storage capacity (2.5-4 cm) within the control section, and are usually coarse textured, or shallow, or both. Water source is precipitation.

Well drained: Water is removed from the soil readily but not rapidly. Excess water flows downward readily into underlying pervious material or laterally as subsurface flow. Soils have intermediate available water storage capacity (4-5 cm) within the control section, and are generally intermediate in texture and depth. Water source is precipitation. On slopes subsurface flow may occur for short durations, but additions are equaled by losses.

Moderately well drained: Water is removed from the soil somewhat slowly in relation to supply. Excess water is removed somewhat slowly due to low perviousness, shallow water table, lack of gradient, or some combination of these. Soils have intermediate to high water storage capacity (5-6 cm) within the control section and are usually medium to fined textured. Precipitation is the dominant water source in medium to fine textured soils; precipitation and significant additions by subsurface flow are necessary in coarse textured soils.

Imperfectly drained: Water is removed from the soil sufficiently slowly in relation to supply, to keep the soil wet for a significant part of the growing season. Excess water moves slowly downward if precipitation is the major supply. If subsurface water or groundwater, or both, is the main source, the flow rate may vary but the soil remains wet for a significant part of the growing season. Precipitation is the main source if available water storage capacity is high; contribution by subsurface flow or groundwater flow, or both, increases as available water storage capacity decreases. Soils have a wide range in available water supply, texture, and depth, and are gleyed phases of well drained subgroups.

Poorly drained: Water is removed so slowly in relation to supply that the soil remains wet for a comparatively large part of the time the soil is not frozen. Excess water is evident in the soil for a large part of the time. Subsurface flow or groundwater flow, or both, in addition to precipitation are the main water sources; there may also be a perched water table, with precipitation exceeding evapotranspiration. Soils have a wide range in available water storage capacity, texture, and depth, and are gleyed subgroups, Gleysols, and Organic soils.

Very poorly drained: Water is removed from the soil so slowly that the water table remains at or on the surface for the greater part of the time the soil is not frozen. Excess water is present in the soil for the greater part of the time. Groundwater flow and subsurface flow are the major water sources. Precipitation is less important except where there is a perched water table with precipitation exceeding evapotranspiration. Soils have a wide range in available water storage capacity, texture, and depth, and are either Gleysolic or Organic.
Not applicable: Drainage not applicable (rock, ice, etc)

attr.attrdef: Parent material texture - first (uppermost): The texture class of the underlying parent material. First used in SLC 3.0.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/pmtex1.html

edom.edomvd: Very Coarse: Very Coarse (USDA Texture Classes: VCS,CS,S,GS,CBS).
Coarse: Coarse (USDA Texture Classes: FS,LCS,LS,LFS,GLS,CBLS).
Moderately Coarse: Moderately Coarse (USDA Texture Classes: VFS,LVFS,CSL,SL,FSL,GSL,CBSL,GFSL).
Medium: Medium (USDA Texture Classes: VFSL,L,SIL,SI,GL,GSIL).
Moderately Fine: Moderately Fine (USDA Texture Classes: SCL,FSCL,VFSCL,CL,SICL,GSCL,GL,CBCL).
Fine: Fine (USDA Texture Classes: SC,SIC,C,GSIC).
Very Fine: Very Fine (USDA Texture Classes: HC (more than 60% clay).
Coarse Skeletal: Coarse Skeletal (USDA Texture Classes: VGS, VGLS).
Medium Skeletal: Medium Skeletal (USDA Texture Classes: VGSL, VGL).
Fine Skeletal: Fine Skeletal (USDA Texture Classes: VGC).
Fragmental: Fragmental
Stratified (Mineral): Stratified (Mineral)
Stratified (Mineral and Organic): Stratified (Mineral and Organic)
Fibric: Fibric
Mesic: Mesic
Humic: Humic
Undifferentiated: Undifferentiated
Not Applicable: Not Applicable

attr.attrdef: Parent material texture - second: The texture class of the second underlying parent material. First used in SLC 3.0.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/pmtex2.html

edom.edomvd: Very Coarse: Very Coarse (USDA Texture Classes: VCS,CS,S,GS,CBS).
Coarse: Coarse (USDA Texture Classes: FS,LCS,LS,LFS,GLS,CBLS).
Moderately Coarse: Moderately Coarse (USDA Texture Classes: VFS,LVFS,CSL,SL,FSL,GSL,CBSL,GFSL).
Medium: Medium (USDA Texture Classes: VFSL,L,SIL,SI,GL,GSIL).
Moderately Fine: Moderately Fine (USDA Texture Classes: SCL,FSCL,VFSCL,CL,SICL,GSCL,GL,CBCL).
Fine: Fine (USDA Texture Classes: SC,SIC,C,GSIC).
Very Fine: Very Fine (USDA Texture Classes: HC (more than 60% clay).
Coarse Skeletal: Coarse Skeletal (USDA Texture Classes: VGS, VGLS).
Medium Skeletal: Medium Skeletal (USDA Texture Classes: VGSL, VGL).
Fine Skeletal: Fine Skeletal (USDA Texture Classes: VGC).
Fragmental: Fragmental
Stratified (Mineral): Stratified (Mineral)
Stratified (Mineral and Organic): Stratified (Mineral and Organic)
Fibric: Fibric
Mesic: Mesic
Humic: Humic
Undifferentiated: Undifferentiated
Not Applicable: Not Applicable

attr.attrdef: Parent material texture - third: The texture class of the third underlying parent material. First used in SLC 3.0.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/pmtex3.html

edom.edomvd: Very Coarse: Very Coarse (USDA Texture Classes: VCS,CS,S,GS,CBS).
Coarse: Coarse (USDA Texture Classes: FS,LCS,LS,LFS,GLS,CBLS).
Moderately Coarse: Moderately Coarse (USDA Texture Classes: VFS,LVFS,CSL,SL,FSL,GSL,CBSL,GFSL).
Medium: Medium (USDA Texture Classes: VFSL,L,SIL,SI,GL,GSIL).
Moderately Fine: Moderately Fine (USDA Texture Classes: SCL,FSCL,VFSCL,CL,SICL,GSCL,GL,CBCL).
Fine: Fine (USDA Texture Classes: SC,SIC,C,GSIC).
Very Fine: Very Fine (USDA Texture Classes: HC (more than 60% clay).
Coarse Skeletal: Coarse Skeletal (USDA Texture Classes: VGS, VGLS).
Medium Skeletal: Medium Skeletal (USDA Texture Classes: VGSL, VGL).
Fine Skeletal: Fine Skeletal (USDA Texture Classes: VGC).
Fragmental: Fragmental
Stratified (Mineral): Stratified (Mineral)
Stratified (Mineral and Organic): Stratified (Mineral and Organic)
Fibric: Fibric
Mesic: Mesic
Humic: Humic
Undifferentiated: Undifferentiated
Not Applicable: Not Applicable

attr.attrdef: Parent material chemical property - first (uppermost): The chemical composition class of the upper layer parent material.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/pmchem1.html

edom.edomvd: Undifferentiated: Undifferentiated acidity and/or calcareousness
Extremely / Strongly Acidic: pH < 5.6
Medium Acid to Neutral: pH 5.6 - 7.4
Weakly Calcareous: < 6 CaCO3 equivalent (%)
Moderately / Very Strongly Calcareous: 6 - 40 CaCO3 equivalent (%)
Extremely Calcareous: > 40 CaCO3 equivalent (%)
Calcareous and Saline: Calcareous and Saline
Not Applicable: Not Applicable

attr.attrdef: Parent material chemical property - second : The chemical composition class of the second underlying parent material if present.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/pmchem2.html

edom.edomvd: Undifferentiated: Undifferentiated acidity and/or calcareousness
Extremely / Strongly Acidic: pH < 5.6
Medium Acid to Neutral: pH 5.6 - 7.4
Weakly Calcareous: < 6 CaCO3 equivalent (%)
Moderately / Very Strongly Calcareous: 6 - 40 CaCO3 equivalent (%)
Extremely Calcareous: > 40 CaCO3 equivalent (%)
Calcareous and Saline: Calcareous and Saline
Not Applicable: Not Applicable

attr.attrdef: Parent material chemical property - third : The chemical composition class of the third, underlying parent material if present.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/pmchem3.html

edom.edomvd: Undifferentiated: Undifferentiated acidity and/or calcareousness
Extremely / Strongly Acidic: pH < 5.6
Medium Acid to Neutral: pH 5.6 - 7.4
Weakly Calcareous: < 6 CaCO3 equivalent (%)
Moderately / Very Strongly Calcareous: 6 - 40 CaCO3 equivalent (%)
Extremely Calcareous: > 40 CaCO3 equivalent (%)
Calcareous and Saline: Calcareous and Saline
Not Applicable: Not Applicable

attr.attrdef: Mode of deposition - first (uppermost): The mode of deposition of the uppermost underlying parent material. First used in SLC 3.0
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/mdep1.html

edom.edomvd: Anthropogenic: Materials modified by people,including those associated with mineral exploitation and waste disposal. They include materials deposited as a result of human activities or geological materials modified artificially so that their physical properties (structure, cohesion, compaction) have been drastically altered. Examples are areas of landfill, spoil heaps, open-pit mines and levelled irrigated areas.
Colluvial: Perennially frozen, loamy-textured, colluviated till: the material is underlain by thick ground ice.
Eolian: Eolian material deposited by wind: uniform deposit of very fine sand and silt.
Fluvioeolian: Fluvioeolian
Fluviolacustrine: Fluviolacustrine
Fluvial: These sediments generally consist of gravel and sand with a minor fraction of silt and rarely of clay. The gravels are typically rounded and contain interstitial sand.

Fen Peat: These deposits consist of sedge peat derived primarily from sedges with inclusions of partially decayed stems of shrubs formed in a eutrophic environment due to the close association of the material with mineral-rich waters.

Forest Peat: This class is used for forest peatcovered or forest peat-filled areas where the water table is at or above the peat surface. The dominant peat materials are shallow to deep mesic to humic forest and fen peat formed in a eutrophic environment resulting from strong water movement from the margins or other mineral sources.

Glaciofluvial: Material moved by glaciers and subsequently sorted and deposited by streams flowing from the melting ice. The deposits are stratified and may occur in the form of outwash plains, deltas, kames eskers, and kame terraces. See also glacial drift and till.

Glaciolacustrine: Used where there is evidence that the lacustrine materials were deposited in contact with glacial ice. One of the following characteristics must be present:
kettles or an otherwise irregular surface that is neither simply the result of normal settling and compaction in silt nor the result of piping slump structures resulting from loss of support caused by melting of retaining ice presence of numerous ice-rafted stones in the lacustrine silts.
Glaciomarine: Glaciomarine

Lacustrine: Sediment, generally consisting of either stratified fine sand, silt, and clay deposited on the lake bed, or moderately-well sorted, stratified sand and coarse materials that consist of near lake shore or beach deposits. These materials have either settled from suspension in bodies of standing fresh water or accumulated at their margins through wave action.
Lacustro-Till: Lacustro-Till

Marine: Unconsolidated deposits of clay, silt, sand, or gravel that are well to moderately well sorted and well to moderately well stratified (in some places containing shells). The deposits have settled from suspension in salt or brackish water bodies or have accumulated at their margins through shoreline processes such as wave action and longshore drift. Nonfossiliferous deposits may be judged marine if they are located in an area that may reasonably be considered to have contained salt water at the time the deposits were formed.
Residual: Unconsolidated, weathered, or partly weathered mineral soil material that accumulates by in situ disintegration of bedrock.

Saprolite: This material is rock and contains a high proportion of residual silts and clays formed by alteration, chiefly by chemical weathering.
The rock remains in a coherent state, interstitial grain relationships are undisturbed, and no downhill movement due to gravity has occurred. The process is assumed to be active. Examples: rotten rock containing corestones.

Sedimentary Peat: Coprogenous earth is composed of aquatic plant debris modified by aquatic animals. It makes slightly viscous water suspensions and is slightly plastic but not sticky. The material shrinks upon drying to form clods that are difficult to rewet and commonly crack along horizontal planes. It has very few or no plant fragments recognizable to the naked eye, a pyrophosphate index of 5 or more, and a dry color value of less than 5.

Sphagnum Peat: These deposits consist of sphagnum or forest peat formed in an ombrotrophic environment caused by the slightly elevated nature of the bog. They tend to be disassociated from nutrient-rich ground water or surrounding mineral soils.
Till (Morainal): Morainal material (till) deposited by glacial ice: a mixture of boulders, sand, silt, and clay.

Undifferentiated mineral: A sequence of more than three types of genetic mineral materials outcropping on a steep erosional escarpment. This complex class is to be used where units relating to individual genetic materials cannot be delimited separately at the scale of mapping. It may include colluvium derived from the various genetic materials and resting upon the scarp slope.
Undifferentiated organic: A layered sequence of more than three undifferentiated types of organic material (>30% organic matter by weight).
Volcanic : Volcanic pumice and ash.
Undifferentiated: Bedrock, undifferentiated
Igneous, acidic: Igneous, acidic bedrock (dominantly granite)
Igneous, basic: Igneous, basic bedrock (dominantly basalt)
Igneous, basic coarse: Igneous, basic coarse bedrock (coarse grained basalts)
Igneous, basic fine grained: Igneous, basic fine grained bedrock (dominantly andesites)
Calcareous: Calcareous bedrock (dominantly sandstone and shale)
Limestone: Limestone bedrock (limestone and dolomite)
Shale: Shale bedrock
Sandstone: Sandstone bedrock
Siltstone and mudstone: Siltstone and mudstone bedrock
Schist and phyllite: Schist and phyllite bedrock
Slate: Slate bedrock
Quartzite: Quartzite bedrock
Gneiss: Gneiss bedrock
Not Applicable: Not Applicable

attr.attrdef: Mode of deposition - second: The mode of deposition of the second underlying parent material. First used in SLC 3.0
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/mdep2.html

edom.edomvd: Anthropogenic: Materials modified by people,including those associated with mineral exploitation and waste disposal. They include materials deposited as a result of human activities or geological materials modified artificially so that their physical properties (structure, cohesion, compaction) have been drastically altered. Examples are areas of landfill, spoil heaps, open-pit mines and levelled irrigated areas.
Colluvial: Perennially frozen, loamy-textured, colluviated till: the material is underlain by thick ground ice.
Eolian: Eolian material deposited by wind: uniform deposit of very fine sand and silt.
Fluvioeolian: Fluvioeolian
Fluviolacustrine: Fluviolacustrine
Fluvial: These sediments generally consist of gravel and sand with a minor fraction of silt and rarely of clay. The gravels are typically rounded and contain interstitial sand.

Fen Peat: These deposits consist of sedge peat derived primarily from sedges with inclusions of partially decayed stems of shrubs formed in a eutrophic environment due to the close association of the material with mineral-rich waters.

Forest Peat: This class is used for forest peatcovered or forest peat-filled areas where the water table is at or above the peat surface. The dominant peat materials are shallow to deep mesic to humic forest and fen peat formed in a eutrophic environment resulting from strong water movement from the margins or other mineral sources.

Glaciofluvial: Material moved by glaciers and subsequently sorted and deposited by streams flowing from the melting ice. The deposits are stratified and may occur in the form of outwash plains, deltas, kames eskers, and kame terraces. See also glacial drift and till.

Glaciolacustrine: Used where there is evidence that the lacustrine materials were deposited in contact with glacial ice. One of the following characteristics must be present:
kettles or an otherwise irregular surface that is neither simply the result of normal settling and compaction in silt nor the result of piping slump structures resulting from loss of support caused by melting of retaining ice presence of numerous ice-rafted stones in the lacustrine silts.
Glaciomarine: Glaciomarine

Lacustrine: Sediment, generally consisting of either stratified fine sand, silt, and clay deposited on the lake bed, or moderately-well sorted, stratified sand and coarse materials that consist of near lake shore or beach deposits. These materials have either settled from suspension in bodies of standing fresh water or accumulated at their margins through wave action.
Lacustro-Till: Lacustro-Till

Marine: Unconsolidated deposits of clay, silt, sand, or gravel that are well to moderately well sorted and well to moderately well stratified (in some places containing shells). The deposits have settled from suspension in salt or brackish water bodies or have accumulated at their margins through shoreline processes such as wave action and longshore drift. Nonfossiliferous deposits may be judged marine if they are located in an area that may reasonably be considered to have contained salt water at the time the deposits were formed.
Residual: Unconsolidated, weathered, or partly weathered mineral soil material that accumulates by in situ disintegration of bedrock.

Saprolite: This material is rock and contains a high proportion of residual silts and clays formed by alteration, chiefly by chemical weathering.
The rock remains in a coherent state, interstitial grain relationships are undisturbed, and no downhill movement due to gravity has occurred. The process is assumed to be active. Examples: rotten rock containing corestones.

Sedimentary Peat: Coprogenous earth is composed of aquatic plant debris modified by aquatic animals. It makes slightly viscous water suspensions and is slightly plastic but not sticky. The material shrinks upon drying to form clods that are difficult to rewet and commonly crack along horizontal planes. It has very few or no plant fragments recognizable to the naked eye, a pyrophosphate index of 5 or more, and a dry color value of less than 5.

Sphagnum Peat: These deposits consist of sphagnum or forest peat formed in an ombrotrophic environment caused by the slightly elevated nature of the bog. They tend to be disassociated from nutrient-rich ground water or surrounding mineral soils.
Till (Morainal): Morainal material (till) deposited by glacial ice: a mixture of boulders, sand, silt, and clay.

Undifferentiated mineral: A sequence of more than three types of genetic mineral materials outcropping on a steep erosional escarpment. This complex class is to be used where units relating to individual genetic materials cannot be delimited separately at the scale of mapping. It may include colluvium derived from the various genetic materials and resting upon the scarp slope.
Undifferentiated organic: A layered sequence of more than three undifferentiated types of organic material (>30% organic matter by weight).
Volcanic : Volcanic pumice and ash.
Undifferentiated: Bedrock, undifferentiated
Igneous, acidic: Igneous, acidic bedrock (dominantly granite)
Igneous, basic: Igneous, basic bedrock (dominantly basalt)
Igneous, basic coarse: Igneous, basic coarse bedrock (coarse grained basalts)
Igneous, basic fine grained: Igneous, basic fine grained bedrock (dominantly andesites)
Calcareous: Calcareous bedrock (dominantly sandstone and shale)
Limestone: Limestone bedrock (limestone and dolomite)
Shale: Shale bedrock
Sandstone: Sandstone bedrock
Siltstone and mudstone: Siltstone and mudstone bedrock
Schist and phyllite: Schist and phyllite bedrock
Slate: Slate bedrock
Quartzite: Quartzite bedrock
Gneiss: Gneiss bedrock
Not Applicable: Not Applicable

attr.attrdef: Mode of deposition - third: The mode of deposition of the third underlying parent material. First used in SLC 3.0
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/mdep3.html

edom.edomvd: Anthropogenic: Materials modified by people,including those associated with mineral exploitation and waste disposal. They include materials deposited as a result of human activities or geological materials modified artificially so that their physical properties (structure, cohesion, compaction) have been drastically altered. Examples are areas of landfill, spoil heaps, open-pit mines and levelled irrigated areas.
Colluvial: Perennially frozen, loamy-textured, colluviated till: the material is underlain by thick ground ice.
Eolian: Eolian material deposited by wind: uniform deposit of very fine sand and silt.
Fluvioeolian: Fluvioeolian
Fluviolacustrine: Fluviolacustrine
Fluvial: These sediments generally consist of gravel and sand with a minor fraction of silt and rarely of clay. The gravels are typically rounded and contain interstitial sand.

Fen Peat: These deposits consist of sedge peat derived primarily from sedges with inclusions of partially decayed stems of shrubs formed in a eutrophic environment due to the close association of the material with mineral-rich waters.

Forest Peat: This class is used for forest peatcovered or forest peat-filled areas where the water table is at or above the peat surface. The dominant peat materials are shallow to deep mesic to humic forest and fen peat formed in a eutrophic environment resulting from strong water movement from the margins or other mineral sources.

Glaciofluvial: Material moved by glaciers and subsequently sorted and deposited by streams flowing from the melting ice. The deposits are stratified and may occur in the form of outwash plains, deltas, kames eskers, and kame terraces. See also glacial drift and till.

Glaciolacustrine: Used where there is evidence that the lacustrine materials were deposited in contact with glacial ice. One of the following characteristics must be present:
kettles or an otherwise irregular surface that is neither simply the result of normal settling and compaction in silt nor the result of piping slump structures resulting from loss of support caused by melting of retaining ice presence of numerous ice-rafted stones in the lacustrine silts.
Glaciomarine: Glaciomarine

Lacustrine: Sediment, generally consisting of either stratified fine sand, silt, and clay deposited on the lake bed, or moderately-well sorted, stratified sand and coarse materials that consist of near lake shore or beach deposits. These materials have either settled from suspension in bodies of standing fresh water or accumulated at their margins through wave action.
Lacustro-Till: Lacustro-Till

Marine: Unconsolidated deposits of clay, silt, sand, or gravel that are well to moderately well sorted and well to moderately well stratified (in some places containing shells). The deposits have settled from suspension in salt or brackish water bodies or have accumulated at their margins through shoreline processes such as wave action and longshore drift. Nonfossiliferous deposits may be judged marine if they are located in an area that may reasonably be considered to have contained salt water at the time the deposits were formed.
Residual: Unconsolidated, weathered, or partly weathered mineral soil material that accumulates by in situ disintegration of bedrock.

Saprolite: This material is rock and contains a high proportion of residual silts and clays formed by alteration, chiefly by chemical weathering.
The rock remains in a coherent state, interstitial grain relationships are undisturbed, and no downhill movement due to gravity has occurred. The process is assumed to be active. Examples: rotten rock containing corestones.

Sedimentary Peat: Coprogenous earth is composed of aquatic plant debris modified by aquatic animals. It makes slightly viscous water suspensions and is slightly plastic but not sticky. The material shrinks upon drying to form clods that are difficult to rewet and commonly crack along horizontal planes. It has very few or no plant fragments recognizable to the naked eye, a pyrophosphate index of 5 or more, and a dry color value of less than 5.

Sphagnum Peat: These deposits consist of sphagnum or forest peat formed in an ombrotrophic environment caused by the slightly elevated nature of the bog. They tend to be disassociated from nutrient-rich ground water or surrounding mineral soils.
Till (Morainal): Morainal material (till) deposited by glacial ice: a mixture of boulders, sand, silt, and clay.

Undifferentiated mineral: A sequence of more than three types of genetic mineral materials outcropping on a steep erosional escarpment. This complex class is to be used where units relating to individual genetic materials cannot be delimited separately at the scale of mapping. It may include colluvium derived from the various genetic materials and resting upon the scarp slope.
Undifferentiated organic: A layered sequence of more than three undifferentiated types of organic material (>30% organic matter by weight).
Volcanic : Volcanic pumice and ash.
Undifferentiated: Bedrock, undifferentiated
Igneous, acidic: Igneous, acidic bedrock (dominantly granite)
Igneous, basic: Igneous, basic bedrock (dominantly basalt)
Igneous, basic coarse: Igneous, basic coarse bedrock (coarse grained basalts)
Igneous, basic fine grained: Igneous, basic fine grained bedrock (dominantly andesites)
Calcareous: Calcareous bedrock (dominantly sandstone and shale)
Limestone: Limestone bedrock (limestone and dolomite)
Shale: Shale bedrock
Sandstone: Sandstone bedrock
Siltstone and mudstone: Siltstone and mudstone bedrock
Schist and phyllite: Schist and phyllite bedrock
Slate: Slate bedrock
Quartzite: Quartzite bedrock
Gneiss: Gneiss bedrock
Not Applicable: Not Applicable

attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/order2.html

attr.attrdef: Soil Great Group (2nd edition): Identifies the soil great group according to the Canadian System of Soil Classification 2nd edition
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/g_group2.html

attr.attrdef: Soil Subgroup (2nd edition): Identifies the soil subgroup according to the Canadian System of Soil Classification, 2nd edition.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/s_group2.html

attr.attrdef: Soil Order (3rd edition): Identifies the soil order according to the Canadian System of Soil Classification 3rd edition.
attr.attrdefs: Canadian Soil Information Service (CanSIS). The complete definition of this attribute is found at http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/nsdb/soil/v2/snt/order3.html

dataqual.logic:
Domain Consistency: Custom data error check programs have been run to check the geospatial attribute data, the Soil Names Table, Soil Layer Table and the Component Table against each other; most errors identified from this comprehensive check routine have been corrected but some may remain.
Format Consistency: The required standard fields for this geospatial attribute file, and the data recorded therein, comply with the National Soil Database structure specifications.
dataqual.complete: Some fields may contain missing values. This is expected, as the fields are part of the National Soil Database data model, and data for that field may not have been collected during some of the detailed soil surveys that were used to populate ABSID. ABSID does not cover the whole of the the province of Alberta.
